intro: Mascagnia hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy mascagnia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family, which includes milkweeds and other toxic plants. The plant is characterized by its hairy, succulent stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers that range in color from yellow to orange. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and open woodlands. The leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance.
